Introduction

Intussusception is a medical emergency characterized by the telescoping of a segment of the intestine into an adjacent segment, leading to obstruction, ischemia, and potential necrosis.  This condition affects primarily infants and young children (particularly age 6 months to 3 years) but can occur at older ages.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Intussusception occurs when a segment of the intestine telescopes into an adjacent segment (

figure 1
).  This can lead to impaired venous return of the invaginated segment, causing ischemia and necrosis of the intestinal wall.  Although the majority of cases are idiopathic, some cases are associated with viral infections (eg, adenovirus) that stimulate growth of lymphoid follicles within the small intestine (ie, Peyer patches).  This lymphoid hyperplasia can act as a physiologic lead point that becomes trapped by peristalsis and is dragged into a distal segment of the intestine.  The most common location is at the ileocecal junction, likely due to a dense concentration of Peyer patches in the terminal ileum.



Approximately 25% of patients with intussusception have a pathologic lead point for bowel invagination.  The lead point is generally an anatomic abnormality (eg, Meckel diverticulum, polyp, tumor) within the intestinal lumen that is forced into the distal bowel segment during waves of peristalsis.  Risk factors that predispose to intussusception include:



  • Age:  infants and young children (age 6 months to 3 years)
  • Prior intussusception
  • Recent intestinal infections:  Viral infections may trigger intussusception by stimulating lymphoid hyperplasia in the intestinal tract.  The oral rotavirus vaccination has also been associated with intussusception.
  • Underlying disorders:  Pathologic lead points may arise from Meckel diverticulum (
    figure 2
    ), bowel wall purpura from Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura (
    figure 3
    ), or inspissated stool in cystic fibrosis (
    figure 4
    ).  An underlying disorder should be suspected in patients with recurrent episodes or if the presentation is atypical (eg, older child).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of intussusception can vary but often includes:



  • Severe, intermittent abdominal pain that lasts about 15-20 minutes (corresponding to contraction of the telescoped bowel during peristalsis) and alternates with pain-free periods (when the bowel is not contracting).  During the pain episodes, the patient is generally inconsolable and has their legs flexed and drawn into the abdomen in severe discomfort.  The pain is crampy and progressively increases in frequency and severity.  Pain is usually accompanied by vomiting that may become bilious if the obstruction persists.
  • Relatively benign abdominal examination in-between painful episodes (ie, no abdominal tenderness or distension).
  • "Sausage-shaped" mass (corresponding to invagination of the ileum into the colon) that may occasionally be palpable in the right side of the abdomen.
  • Blood in stools:  may be indicative of compromised circulation to the intestines as intestinal obstruction continues, causing ischemia of the involved segment.  Patients may initially have intestinal bleeding only detectable on hemoccult testing; however, if untreated, this can progress to grossly bloody "currant jelly" stools (due to mixture of blood and mucus).
  • Episodes of lethargy:  As the disease progresses, lethargy occurs and, in a minority of cases, may be the sole presenting sign (particularly in infants).

Differential diagnosis



Intussusception may present with symptoms similar to those seen in other disorders, including:



  • Gastroenteritis:  may also initially present with abdominal pain and vomiting.  Intussusception is more likely if there are characteristic painful episodes, a palpable mass, or episodes of lethargy as the illness progresses.
  • Acute appendicitis:  may present with fever, right lower-quadrant abdominal pain, anorexia, and vomiting.  However, the pain of appendicitis is constant rather than episodic, and bloody stools are not seen.
  • Incarcerated inguinal hernias (
    figure 5
    ):  may cause inconsolable pain and distension.  However, pain would likely be persistent and have a tender, inflamed inguinal mass or bulge on examination.
  • Midgut malrotation with volvulus (
    figure 6
    ):  typically presents with severe, constant abdominal pain with bilious vomiting.
  • Meckel diverticulum:  can present with rectal bleeding but is typically painless.  In some cases, it can function as a pathologic lead point and present with intussusception.

Diagnostic evaluation



The approach for diagnosis and management of patients with suspected intussusception depends on the initial presentation:



  • Typical presentation:  Stable patients who initially present with findings highly suspicious for intussusception (eg, toddler with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and bloody stools) may proceed directly to nonoperative reduction.
  • Atypical presentation:  Most patients with intussusception have atypical presentations (eg, lethargy alone in an infant) and may not have classic findings.  Therefore, a high index of suspicion is needed, particularly if the patient has risk factors.  For these patients, initial work-up may begin with imaging.
    • Abdominal ultrasonography:  This is the preferred initial imaging modality, which can demonstrate the characteristic target or bull's-eye sign (ie, 2 concentric circles that represent the telescoped intestinal layers) (
      image 1
      ).  This can be detected even during asymptomatic intervals because the telescoped bowel is still present but not contracting to cause pain.
    • Abdominal radiograph:  For suspected intussusception, radiographs are less sensitive and specific than ultrasonography.  If present, a "crescent sign", a soft-tissue density caused by the intussusceptum overlying gas in the large bowel, is suggestive (
      image 2
      ).  The role of radiographs is to evaluate for mainly bowel perforation (eg, free air under the diaphragm (
      image 3
      )), a potential complication of intussusception that would warrant surgical management.

Management



Regardless of the presentation, supportive care (eg, fluid resuscitation) should be prioritized, particularly in patients with hemodynamic instability (eg, dehydration with tachycardia).



If the patient is otherwise hemodynamically stable, management involves prompt nonoperative reduction.  This is generally performed with either retrograde pneumatic pressure (ie, air enema) or hydrostatic pressure (ie, saline or water-soluble contrast [eg, iodine] enema).  Nonoperative reduction allows for visualization of the intussuscepted bowel and is both diagnostic and therapeutic.



Surgical intervention may be indicated in some cases, including failed enema reduction (nonoperative reduction is unsuccessful in about 30% of intussusception cases), signs of peritonitis (eg, rigid abdomen) or perforation (free air on imaging), and the presence of a pathologic lead point.

Complications and prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and appropriate management, the prognosis for intussusception is generally favorable.  Potential complications of intussusception include:



  • Recurrence:  Following successful reduction, recurrences may occur up to months later in approximately 10% of patients.  If recurrences do occur, further work-up should be considered to evaluate for a possible pathologic lead point.
  • Bowel perforation:  Edema due to venous and lymphatic congestion within the bowel wall can lead to ischemia, necrosis, and bowel perforation.  The risk is greatest in children who have had symptoms for several days, patients with evidence of small bowel obstruction, and patients age <6 months.  In a small percentage (<5%) of patients, nonoperative reduction (pneumatic or hydrostatic) can also be complicated by bowel perforation due to the pressure on friable tissue.  If perforation occurs, air enemas have less risk of causing peritonitis compared to contrast enemas.

Summary



Intussusception (
